facts.text: There is a Government Printing Press at Rashtrapati Bhavan known as Rashtrapati Bhavan Printing Press which is located in the Presidents estate in New Delhi. Jacobs was the General Foreman of this Press.
Every year the budget proposals are printed at this Press under the supervision of Jacobs. As usual, Jacobs supervised the printing of budget proposals in his official capacity in February 1955 also.

Jacobs entered into a conspiracy to divulge the budget proposals on receiving valuable consideration for the same. Consequently the proposals were divulged to D. P. Chadda and were passed on to certain businessmen of Bombay, including Nandlal More and Hiralal G. Kothari through one A. L. Mehra. All this was done against the provisions of the Official Secrets Act, No. XIX of 1923.
Further an offence was committed under the Prevention of Corruption Act, No. II of 1947, also inasmuch as money was paid to Jacobs for divulging the budget proposals.
The same thing happened in February 1956, with respect to the budget proposals for 1956-57.

This was discovered on March 9, 1956, and a case was registered under s. 165-A of the Indian Penal Code, s. 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, s. 5 of the Official Secrets Act and s. 120-B of the Indian Penal Code and investigation started on March 10, 1956.

Pardon was tendered to A. L. Mehra by the Additional District Magistrate on March 23, 1956, under s. 337 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. The four offences mentioned above were specified in the order of the Additional District Magistrate tendering pardon to Mehra.

Owing to technical legal difficulties a complaint under s. 5 of the Official Secrets Act read with s. 120-B of the Indian Penal Code was filed against the persons involved and it was stated in that complaint that proceedings with respect to the charge under s. 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act would be taken separately.

Proceedings then began before a magistrate on this complaint. No proceedings have yet started insofar as the offences under s. 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act and s. 165-A of the Indian Penal Code are concerned.
In the course of these proceedings before the magistrate, the prosecution wanted to examine Mehra as an approver.

Thereupon the accused persons objected that as the proceedings before the magistrate were only under s. 5 of the Official Secrets Act and s. 120-B of the Indian Penal Code, Mehra could not be examined as an approver and in consequence the case could not be committed to the Court of Session but should be disposed of by the magistrate himself.
The magistrate held that Mehra could be treated as an approver and proceedings before him were therefore in the nature of commitment proceedings.

There was a revision to the Sessions Judge who took the view that as the proceedings before the magistrate were under s. 5 of the Official Secrets Act read with s. 120-B of the Indian Penal Code and as no pardon could be tendered under s. 337 of the Code of Criminal Procedure for these offences, Mehra could not be treated as an approver and had to be examined as an ordinary witness and the proceedings must be held to be trial proceedings before the magistrate and not commitment proceedings. He therefore recommended to the High Court that the order of the magistrate be set aside.

The High Court upheld the view of the Sessions Judge and ordered accordingly. It granted certificates under Art. 134(1)(c) of the Constitution and that is how these three appeals have been filed by the State before us.
One of the accused has asked for trial by the Court of Session as provided under s. 13(2) of the Official Secrets Act.

legal_issues.text: Whether Mehra could be treated as an approver and examined as such for the purposes of the proceedings before the magistrate which were only under s. 5 of the Official Secrets Act read with s. 120-B of the Indian Penal Code, given that pardon was tendered under s. 337 CrPC specifying four offences including others.

petitioner_arguments.text: The view of the magistrate is correct and Mehra could be treated as an approver and examined as such for the purposes of the proceedings before him.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 337 CrPC (tender of pardon on condition of full disclosure of whole circumstances including subsidiary offences); s. 339 CrPC

petitioner_arguments.text: s. 337(1) contemplates tender of a pardon on condition of the person pardoned making a full and true disclosure of the whole of the circumstances within his knowledge relative to the offence and to every other person concerned, whether as principal or abettor, in the commission thereof and this means that the person to whom pardon is tendered is expected to tell the whole truth including details of any other subsidiary offence which might have been committed in the course of the commission of the offence for which pardon is tendered and therefore the pardon so tendered must be held to include the subsidiary offence.

The specific provision for trial for any other offence which might have been committed in connection with the same matter in s. 339 shows that the pardon would cover the other offence also even though it may not be an offence for which the pardon was and could be tendered.
Cites cases supporting that pardon under s. 337(1) could be tendered not only for offences enumerated therein but also other offences committed in the course of those offences.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Queen-Empress v. Ganga Charan I.L.R. 11 All. 79; Harumal Parmanand v. Emperor A.I.R. 1915 Sind 43; Shiam Sunder v. Emperor A.I.R. 1921 All. 234

respondent_arguments.text: As the proceedings before the magistrate were only under s. 5 of the Official Secrets Act and s. 120-B of the Indian Penal Code, Mehra could not be examined as an approver and in consequence the case could not be committed to the Court of Session but should be disposed of by the magistrate himself.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 337 CrPC (pardon only for specified offences)

court_reasoning.text: A mere perusal of s. 337 of the Code of Criminal Procedure shows that the view of the High Court is correct. Section 337(1) provides for tender of a pardon in respect of the following offences: Any offence triable exclusively by the High Court or Court of Session; Any offence punishable with imprisonment which may extend to seven years; Any offence under IPC ss. 161, 165, 165-A, 216-A, 369, 401, 435 and 477-A.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Pardon can only be tendered with respect to an offence which falls in one of these categories. Offence under s. 5 OSA r/w s.120B IPC does not fall within any.

court_reasoning.text: No such inference could be drawn from s. 339 that pardon covers other offences; s. 339 deals with failure to comply with conditions of pardon, allowing prosecution for the pardoned offence or other connected offences upon forfeiture.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Words of s. 339 are of no help in construing s. 337.

court_reasoning.text: The fact that in the order tendering pardon, s. 5 OSA was mentioned along with other offences does not mean pardon could be tendered for it if not covered by s. 337(1).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Pardon only for three categories in s. 337(1).

court_reasoning.text: Cases cited by appellant refer to different circumstances under s. 339, whether approver complied with conditions; not concerned with whether pardon can be granted under s. 337(1) for offences outside its scope.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Those cases turned on compliance with pardon conditions in s. 339 trials.

court_reasoning.text: Therefore, Mehra to whom pardon has been tendered, could not be examined as an approver in the proceedings which are concerned only with an offence under s. 5 of the Official Secrets Act read with s. 120-B of the Indian Penal Code.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No pardon can be granted under s. 337(1) for offence under s. 5 OSA r/w s. 120B IPC.

holdings.text: Pardon under s. 337 CrPC can only be tendered for offences falling within the three categories specified in s. 337(1); does not extend to subsidiary offences outside those categories.
Mehra cannot be examined as an approver in proceedings concerned only with offence under s. 5 Official Secrets Act read with s. 120-B IPC.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court upheld the High Court's view that Mehra cannot be treated as an approver in proceedings under s. 5 Official Secrets Act r/w s. 120-B IPC as that offence is not covered by s. 337 CrPC for tender of pardon. The State's appeals are dismissed.
